content.definition: Atherosclerotic narrowing or occlusion of the common and/or external iliac arteries causing aortoiliac segment insufficiency. Present in ~30% of PAD patients. May present as isolated iliac disease or in combination with aortic involvement (AIOD). TASC II classification guides treatment strategy.

tasc_classification.TASC_A: Single stenosis ≤3 cm (common or external iliac) - endovascular preferred
tasc_classification.TASC_B: Single stenosis 3-10 cm, two stenoses <5 cm each - endovascular preferred
tasc_classification.TASC_C: Bilateral CIA stenoses, unilateral EIA occlusion - surgical considered
tasc_classification.TASC_D: Infrarenal aortoiliac occlusion, diffuse disease - surgery preferred

diagnosis: ABI: decreased (may be normal at rest, decreased post-exercise)
MRA: alternative to CTA, no iodine

endovascular: Iliac angioplasty and stenting (primary patency 70-80% at 5 years)
Kissing stents for aortic bifurcation disease
surgical: Aortobifemoral bypass (gold standard for TASC D)
Femoral-femoral crossover (unilateral iliac, poor surgical candidate)

clinical_pearls: TASC guides therapy: A/B = endo, C/D = consider surgery
Kissing stents prevent plaque shift at aortic bifurcation
AFB is durable but requires abdominal surgery
Fem-fem crossover useful in unilateral disease, poor candidate
Iliac stenting has better results than femoropopliteal (larger caliber)
